clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Drainage in Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy
clinical_study.official_title: To Drain or Not to Drain in Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy for the Patients With Acutely Inflamed Gallbladder ; a Multicenter Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: During laparoscopic surgery for an acutely inflamed gallbladder, most surgeons routinely insert a drain. However, no consensus has been reached regarding the need for drainage in these cases, and the use of a drain remains controversial. This study is coordinated to find out the surgical outcomes and perioperative morbidity according to the insertion of drain after laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Inverstgators expect that the routine use of a drain after laparoscopic cholecystectomy for an acutely inflamed gallbladder will have no effects on the postoperative morbidity.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Treatment

arm_group.description: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy with drain insertion is performed in this arm.
In this arm, investigators perform only laparoscopic cholecystectomy, and not insert a drain

intervention.description: In the drain insertion group, investigators use the closed suction drain (EZ-VAC®, 200ml, 4.8mm, EG-Medisys, Korea) through a lateral 5-mm trocar and placed it in Morrison's pouch.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- acutely inflamed gallbladder
Exclusion Criteria:
- chronic cholecystitis
- gallbladder polyp or gallbladder cancer
- the patient who underwent reduced port surgery
- the patient who underwent common bile duct exploration during the operation
- the patient who underwent concurrent operation
- the patient who had past history of upper abdominal surgery
- the patient who had a immunodeficiency state
- the case which had a suspicion of delayed bile leakage
- the case which had a incomplete cystic duct ligation
- the patient who underwent open conversion surgery during the operation
- the patient who had a high risk of bleeding
